column4: what kind of link does ln -s /file /path/file make? and would a proper symbolic link be ln -sf /target /path/destination ? i can't tell the difference?
symbolic links, both. -sf means just "force". read "man ln"
i did read it i was using that exact command but it wasn't making symbolic links. modification to /source didn't reflect changes in /path

it's apache stuff /etc/apache2/sites-enabled to /etc/apache2/sites-available , when i do the command and edit /sites-enabled files and go back to /sites-available, the available file is original, where enabled file has the modifications
which tells me i'm not making the symbolic link correctly because it's not linked to the orig file it's making a new file
then you did the command wrong and haven't created a link. "ls -l /etc/apache2/sites-enabled"
ah, ls not ln? that would be why lol
nope, paste the output of that command please
to create the links, use "sudo ln -s /etc/apache2/sites-available/site1  /etc/apache2/sites-enabled/"
but anyways, any change to /etc/apache2/sites-enabled/000-default  will apply to   ../sites-available/default  too(its the same file)
yeah, i know that part, i'm backtracking now to figure out how i did it to make them individual files. i missed proper syntax somewhere
but " lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 26 2010-06-10 05:03 000-default -> ../sites-available/default" is a correct symlink
i'm thinking then i DID do the command right, i made the error by pointing to a wrong file and naming the files wrong
thanks again though i got it working right now
so remove the link and use that command mentioned by unop
